abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Provincial and Rural
            Infrastructure Project for Cambodia were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was high; Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: a well
            formulated sector policy and strategy are essential if gains
            are to be sustained. The likely passage of the roads law and
            approval of the rural roads policy are important, but do not
            fulfill the need for a well formulated policy and strategy
            to guide the development of the sector, and thereafter
            ensure its sustainability. The role and importance of a road
            network's 'missing middle' needs to be
            documented and understood. There is a general understanding,
            supported by extensive literature on rural roads, which all-
            weather good quality roads at the subnational level
            contribute to the improved health and welfare of those
            served. Contextual constraints need to be identified and
            accommodated. The project sought to strengthen the capacity
            of small to medium-sized contractors and thereby begin the
            process of moving from force account to the contracting out
            of maintenance works. For Monitoring and Evaluation
            (M&E) frameworks to be useful, they have to employ
            indicators that are relevant and useful to decision-makers.
            Lasting improvements in governance cannot be served by
            establishment of parallel systems.
